comment.author: 24231207@N07
comment._content: I believe the abbreviation is Linc. Daniels. As in Lincoln Daniels.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content:
Thanks!  You are correct that the abbreviation (a bit illegible in the negative) is "Linc." and it stands for "Lincoln."  I hunted in one of the Prints and Photographs Division's photo files and found a photographic print that corresponds to this image.  The Bain News Service caption on the back, dated Jan. 27, 1913, says, "Linc. Daniels has been visiting New York and he has regretted all through his stay that he did not bring his compass with him. Linc. says it is much easier to find your way through the woods near Sebago Lake in Maine, where he lives, than through the streets of New York...Linc. is 82 years old and the oldest guide in all Maine."

We'll flesh out the title and date in our source description and reload it to Flickr.

comment.author: 45888090@N05
comment._content: Linc Daniels was one of the most successful Sebago Lake guides, and at a time when big landlock salmon were plentiful. It's quite likely that Linc used fishing rods made by his brother, James B. Daniels of Auburn (ME).
